proposition: Nuclear power causes fewer deaths per unit of energy than coal

turns.user_message: How do the health and safety impacts of nuclear power compare to coal power in terms of deaths caused per unit of energy produced?
turns.unknown_model_response:
When comparing the health and safety impacts of nuclear power and coal power, the evidence is clear: coal power causes significantly more deaths per unit of energy produced than nuclear power. This is supported by extensive data from energy lifecycle analyses that account for mining, processing, transportation, operation, and waste management across both industries.

Coal, in particular, is associated with a wide range of health risks. Mining operations lead to fatal accidents and chronic respiratory diseases such as black lung. Surface mining and mountaintop removal destroy ecosystems and communities. When burned, coal releases particulate matter, sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, and mercury, all of which contribute to respiratory illnesses, cardiovascular diseases, and premature deaths. According to the World Health Organization and other public health institutions, air pollution from coal-fired power plants is responsible for hundreds of thousands of premature deaths annually—many of which can be directly linked to the energy produced.

In contrast, nuclear power has an extremely low death rate per unit of energy. The mining of uranium, while not risk-free, is vastly less dangerous than coal mining when normalized to the amount of energy produced. Operational risks at nuclear plants are also exceedingly rare, with no direct deaths from radiation in the civilian nuclear industry under normal operations. Even in the case of major accidents like Chernobyl and Fukushima, the long-term health impacts and deaths are significantly lower than the annual toll from coal when measured per terawatt-hour of energy generated.

Studies from reputable institutions like the International Energy Agency, the World Nuclear Association, and peer-reviewed energy lifecycle analyses consistently show that nuclear power has one of the lowest death rates per unit of energy among all energy sources. Coal, by comparison, is orders of magnitude more deadly.

Therefore, from a public health and safety perspective, nuclear power is a far more benign option than coal in terms of lives lost per unit of energy produced.
